messages: d1ecb99b19140444b80e4035bfe0dd67 (04:04): Morning, all
c55963a3bec158d36e87abc2f9085a9e (04:05): ok, i've decided that i'm not interested in live upgrade
c55963a3bec158d36e87abc2f9085a9e (04:05): what's the correct way to do a dead upgrade? :)
c55963a3bec158d36e87abc2f9085a9e (04:05): do i just boot from the dvd and ask it to upgrade my zfs partition?
c55963a3bec158d36e87abc2f9085a9e (04:06): hi jmcp
33ed8c96b2b06385e426e5bcf6935cf8 (04:06): timeless: I think there's still an issue with zfs and live-upgrade
c55963a3bec158d36e87abc2f9085a9e (04:07): jmcp: well, er :)
d1ecb99b19140444b80e4035bfe0dd67 (04:07): I think there's an issue with ZFS and *any* upgrade
d1ecb99b19140444b80e4035bfe0dd67 (04:07): (except data-only FSs)
c55963a3bec158d36e87abc2f9085a9e (04:07): ok, well, i have a /ufsroot
c55963a3bec158d36e87abc2f9085a9e (04:07): can i tell liveupgrade to upgrade that?
33ed8c96b2b06385e426e5bcf6935cf8 (04:08): timeless: I'd hang off from doing a liveupgrade with your zfsroot just yet
c55963a3bec158d36e87abc2f9085a9e (04:08): i kinda need to get at least brandz working
c55963a3bec158d36e87abc2f9085a9e (04:09): and someone pointed out that snv43 exists as does a brandz for 43
c55963a3bec158d36e87abc2f9085a9e (04:09): i snapshotted my zfs, so it's about as safe as can be :)
c55963a3bec158d36e87abc2f9085a9e (04:11): yeah, liveupgrade really doesn't seem like a good idea
c55963a3bec158d36e87abc2f9085a9e (04:11): suppose i want to do a dead upgrade, what would i do?
c55963a3bec158d36e87abc2f9085a9e (04:11): boot from the dvd and ask it to upgrade my ufs partition?
c55963a3bec158d36e87abc2f9085a9e (04:12): (heck, boot from the dvd and let it rewrite my ufs partition)
d1ecb99b19140444b80e4035bfe0dd67 (04:25): That's the normal thing, yeah
33ed8c96b2b06385e426e5bcf6935cf8 (04:29): gday Tpenta
33ed8c96b2b06385e426e5bcf6935cf8 (04:30): Gman: welcome back
272c868dbdbed152063a7bcfe7b75482 (04:30): heya jmcpAtSun
33ed8c96b2b06385e426e5bcf6935cf8 (04:31): Gman: how's the world of JDS?
33ed8c96b2b06385e426e5bcf6935cf8 (04:31): are you back in NZ yet?
272c868dbdbed152063a7bcfe7b75482 (04:31): good good, just recovering from oscon last week
272c868dbdbed152063a7bcfe7b75482 (04:31): in palo alto atm
272c868dbdbed152063a7bcfe7b75482 (04:31): slept in until about 3pm, and had a walk around
272c868dbdbed152063a7bcfe7b75482 (04:31): now going to catch up on a bit of work, and prepare for HQ next week :)
33ed8c96b2b06385e426e5bcf6935cf8 (04:31): muahahaha
272c868dbdbed152063a7bcfe7b75482 (04:32): indeed
272c868dbdbed152063a7bcfe7b75482 (04:32): walked down palo alto with my enormous gnome tshirt
272c868dbdbed152063a7bcfe7b75482 (04:32): got a few double looks
33ed8c96b2b06385e426e5bcf6935cf8 (04:33): not really surprising
33ed8c96b2b06385e426e5bcf6935cf8 (04:35): yeah, it's a bitch being away from home
272c868dbdbed152063a7bcfe7b75482 (04:37): eh, can't complain too much given i'm lucky enough to be travelling in the first place
33ed8c96b2b06385e426e5bcf6935cf8 (04:39): yeah, there is that
272c868dbdbed152063a7bcfe7b75482 (04:40): looking forward to meeting more opensolaris dudes this week though
272c868dbdbed152063a7bcfe7b75482 (04:41): palo alto is a bit like the set of sideways though
33ed8c96b2b06385e426e5bcf6935cf8 (04:41): I don't think I've seen sideways
33ed8c96b2b06385e426e5bcf6935cf8 (04:41): are you in Pal all week?
272c868dbdbed152063a7bcfe7b75482 (04:42): until thursday evening
272c868dbdbed152063a7bcfe7b75482 (04:43): sideways is that rather odd film about wine set in california
33ed8c96b2b06385e426e5bcf6935cf8 (04:43): with Thomas Haden Church and the bloke who does a lot with Jim Carrey?
272c868dbdbed152063a7bcfe7b75482 (04:44): http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0375063/
c55963a3bec158d36e87abc2f9085a9e (04:44): if there's an nt domain around and it's probably nt5 or better, should i try to enroll my opensolaris box into it's potential kerebros realm? :)
33ed8c96b2b06385e426e5bcf6935cf8 (04:45): yeah, that's the one. I have seen it
33ed8c96b2b06385e426e5bcf6935cf8 (04:47): timeless: possibly because you specified a naming service before that point?
daa08b04a71644cbce3e6e7e5aeeb58e (04:47): the solaris installer really needs an overhaul I mean it works well
daa08b04a71644cbce3e6e7e5aeeb58e (04:47): but could use some eye candy
c55963a3bec158d36e87abc2f9085a9e (04:48): jmcp: yeah i specified dns
daa08b04a71644cbce3e6e7e5aeeb58e (04:48): especially compared to what these hacked up distros are doing these days
c55963a3bec158d36e87abc2f9085a9e (04:48): was i not supposed to do that?
8c27c6238210e78d0cff9690db08116b (04:48): jmcpAtSun, you've heard of DHCP and YP then?
c55963a3bec158d36e87abc2f9085a9e (04:48): i'm used to things that ask me if i want to use dhcp to realize they can get dns servers from the dhcp service
33ed8c96b2b06385e426e5bcf6935cf8 (04:49): I think the installer is playing it safe by not assuming that your DHCP server will actually provide *all* the information that you need
33ed8c96b2b06385e426e5bcf6935cf8 (04:49): g4lt-U60: funnily enough, I actually have
c55963a3bec158d36e87abc2f9085a9e (04:49): the installer could play it safe by prefillying the information from the dhcp server
8c27c6238210e78d0cff9690db08116b (04:49): good god, the bletcherousness of htat simply boggles the imagination
c55963a3bec158d36e87abc2f9085a9e (04:50): it's a good thing i have a second computer that can talk to them
c55963a3bec158d36e87abc2f9085a9e (04:50): i presume that this thing isn't going to destroy my hard drive
c55963a3bec158d36e87abc2f9085a9e (04:50): but it hasn't asked yet :(
c55963a3bec158d36e87abc2f9085a9e (04:51): ooh, there's the upgrade option :)

e6320bbf98fd0b6222b7279be01bcec9 (04:51): i installed nexenta on a usb hard drive, then moved it into a laptop as and ide drive. now i can boot into grub but solaris can't mount the root device. what would i need to change to make this work?

8c27c6238210e78d0cff9690db08116b (04:51): jmcpAtSun, no the reason that the installer exhibits that behavior is that solaris's DHCP client exhibits many levels of brokenness, like not accepting most of the inrformation from the DHCP server without manula intervention
daa08b04a71644cbce3e6e7e5aeeb58e (04:51): did your device name change?
daa08b04a71644cbce3e6e7e5aeeb58e (04:51): check your grub.conf?
33ed8c96b2b06385e426e5bcf6935cf8 (04:52): g4lt-U60: which is something that as long as I know about, I can work around. I've never given it a second thought
8c27c6238210e78d0cff9690db08116b (04:52): yeah, but the installer by definition cannot
e6320bbf98fd0b6222b7279be01bcec9 (04:53): rodrickbrown: yes it would have had to. can i use grub to manually boot the first time so i can get in to change my grub.conf?
daa08b04a71644cbce3e6e7e5aeeb58e (04:54): nailbags, not sure actually consult the grub doc
daa08b04a71644cbce3e6e7e5aeeb58e (04:54): i really have limited exp. with grub

e6320bbf98fd0b6222b7279be01bcec9 (04:58): rodrickbrown: well i know how to do what i'm trying to do in linux. in linux i can press 'e' and change the boot device and the kernel command line. then boot up, enter maintinence mode to change the grub.conf and /etc/fstab, then reboot. i want to do something like that.
33ed8c96b2b06385e426e5bcf6935cf8 (04:59): nailbags|work: you can do that too with grub on Solaris
33ed8c96b2b06385e426e5bcf6935cf8 (04:59): add "-s" to the kernel line
33ed8c96b2b06385e426e5bcf6935cf8 (04:59): you'll have to futz around with the root() setting though
e6320bbf98fd0b6222b7279be01bcec9 (05:00): what does -s do?
33ed8c96b2b06385e426e5bcf6935cf8 (05:00): boots to single user state
